p.i: NOTE: This document is available in a HTML form at the following address: http://springrts.com/dl/LobbyProtocol/

Intro.p: This is a simple text protocol in a "human readable form". I decided for text protocol since it's easier to debug and implement on the client side. It does require some more overhead, but since server and clients do not communicate much anyway, this is not an issue. What really eats the bandwidth is the game itself, not lobby.

We use two terms for "clients": client and an user. At first, user was considered to be a registered client, that means a client that is logged-in. The two terms are used uncleanly though, so you may best think of them as equal.

ul.li: {} = sentence = several words (at least one!) separated by space characters
{} {} ... = two or more sentences. They are separated by TAB characters.
words are always separated by space characters.

Intro.p: Single word arguments are separated by spaces, "sentences" (a sentence is a series of words separated by spaces, denoting a single argument) are separated by TABs. Make sure to replace all TABs in your sentences with spaces (2 or 8 usually)! If you do not, your command is invalid, and will not be read correctly by the server.

Lines sent and received may be of any length. It has been tested with 600 KB long strings and it worked in both directions. Nevertheless, commands like "CLIENTS" still try to divide data into several lines, just to make sure the client will receive them. Since the Delphi lobby client (TASClient) now supports lines of any length, dividing data into several lines is not needed anymore. Though, we keep it just in case, to be compatible with other clients which may emerge in the future. I do not divide data when sending info on battles and clients in battles. This lines may get long, but not longer than a couple of hundred bytes (they should always be under 1 KB in length).

A client must maintain a constant connection with the server. That is if no data is to be transfered, the client must send commands to the server on regular intervals. This ensures that the server can properly detect any network timeouts/disconnects. The server will automatically disconnect a client if no data has been received from it within a certain time period. A client should send some data at least after half that interval passed.
Clients may find out whether a battle is in progress or not by monitoring the battle-founder's status. If his status changes to "in game", the battle's status is also "in game".

A client's status and battle status are assumed to be 0 if not specified otherwise. Each client should assume that every other client's status and battle statuses are 0 if not stated otherwise by the server. So when a client joins the server, he is notified about statuses of those users only, who have status or battle status different from 0. This way we also save some bandwidth (although that is not really an issue here. If we were worried about this protocol taking up too much bandwidth, we would not use a text protocol, would we?).

Most of the commands that notify about some changes are forwarded to the source of the change too. For example: When a client sends a command, the server sends a command to all users in the battle, including the client who sent the command. This is a good practice, because this way the client can synchronize his local status with the server's, after the server has actually updated his status (it also serves as confirmation mechanism).
All commands except for some admin specific commands are listed here. For more details on a specific command, you may have a look at a lobby servers source code, for example SpringLS or ueberserver.
A Client may participate in only one battle at the same time. If he is hosting a battle, he may not participate in other battles at the same time. The server checks for that automatically.
Team colors are currently set by players, perhaps it would be better if only the host would be able to change them?

As of version 0.33, the command syntax has been slightly changed. Messages may now contain IDs: Any message may be prefixed with a message ID. For example: "#123 SAY main hello!"
Server will use this ID with a reply, for example: "#123 SAID main Betalord hello!"
The message ID has only one function: to ease tracking server responses for the client. Using message IDs means that the client can also use synchronous communication (with certain commands), which makes it easier to implement commands that require multiple responses in both directions.
Note that IDs should be non-negative values, in a 31-bit range (0..2147483647). Negative values are reserved for internal handling logic of the server / lobby clients.

To be in sync means, to have the same versions of all the content required to play a game. It works by clients comparing host's hash code with their own. If the two codes match, client should update his battle status and this way telling other clients in the battle that he is synced (or unsynced otherwise). The hash code comes from hashing the mod's file and probably all the dependences too. See unitsync documentation for details.

Hole punching is a computer networking technique for establishing communications between two parties in separate organizations who are both behind restrictive firewalls.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hole_punching
We use it for allowing clients to connect to the lobby server, that would otherwise not be able to.
This will probably not work in LAN mode, especially if combined with players from the internet.

When joining a battle, a client should first acquire his UDP source port from the server before sending the command. Once he has done that and joined the battle, he should keep sendings some UDP packets to the server on regular intervals, just to make sure the router does not forget about it and remove it from its translation table (some routers have timeout as short as 20 seconds, so this should also be the minimum refresh interval). Once the game actually starts, the client lobby should stop sending UDP packets to the server since the OS will not allow it anyway (will not be able to bind the same source port, as it will already be bound by spring.exe). Also, there is no need for it, since spring.exe will keep sending the packets and so keep the port open instead of the lobby client. Once the lobby client detects the user has returned from the game, it should start sending the UDP packets again, in order to keep the "connection" alive. Another thing to note is, that the lobby client does not need to "punch through" like it has to when hosting, since spring.exe will do that anyway.
Just before starting the game, the server will send a command to the user, containing the host's public UDP source port. The lobby cient should replace the battle's port with this one, as it will have to connect to this port and not the original one (acquired through the command).

Before sending the command, the host should try to acquire his UDP source port from the server, just to make sure it can acquire it at all (better to find out it does not work before hosting, than right before starting the game). Nevertheless, the lobby client does not need to keep to refresh this port, since it will not be used to actually host the game. It is just a test to see if it works, not to actually acquire a port for hosting. Each time a new client joins the battle, the server will send a command, telling the host about this client's public UDP source port. The host should remember this information, as he will have to use it when starting the game. Right before starting the game, the host should try to acquire his source port again. This time he will actually use this port to host the game. Upon starting the game, the server will notify all clients participating in his battle about his port, using the command. The host does not need to keep refreshing his connection to keep the port open, as spring.exe will do that for him. Also, upon returning from the game, he does not need to start refreshing it either (as a non-host would have to), since when he will start a new game, he will have to acquire a new source port anyway. This is mostly because some people could play "single-player" games with bots before opening the battle to other players, and spring.exe would of course not keep the connection alive in that case, and upon returning from the game, the port would already be timed-out long ago. This is why the host has to acquire a new port each time it starts a battle.

With match-making, we mean a somewhat abstract way of automating the process of users finding to each other in battle rooms to play a game of a type they like.
For us this means, more specifically, that users get shuffled around hosts (usually autohosts) that support match-making, according to preferences they set, by the hand of a central match planning strategy/algorithm. Match-making enabled hosts have to be marked as such. The current way of doing this is, to let them report a CPU frequency of 6667. This way, each lobby client may choose to visually outline this host property in a certain way or not at all. A user may choose to take part in match-making by entering one of these hosts battle. When a match-maker sends a request for a certain user to switch hosts by sending a command to the server, and the server subsequently sends a to that addressed user, the lobby client must comply by joining that hosts battle-room. To opt-out of the match-making process, a user has to leave the battle-room, after then he may join a non-match-making enabled host. If the request was illegitimate, the server will send to the command issuing user.

For better match-making, you may now use the commands (client) and (server). They allow to initiate games without creating a battle-room first. That means in practise, that we can also initiate multiple games from a single chat-room.

For quasi direct communication between lobby clients, in order to allow faster development cycles, and to keep the lobby protocol from getting bloated unnecessarily, a new set of commands was introduced. They mirror most of the chat commands, but instead of human, user2user chat interaction, these are meant for programmatic, client2client or user2client communication. The server just routes the messages to the intended receiving client(s). They are meant to be used for stuff like standardized auto-host commands, for example a common set of commands and arguments for voting. Commands that may be used through this new communication channel have to be discussed and approved by the lobby-dev meeting first, and be documented in the Inter-lobby-client data exchange protocol. When receiving messages through these new lobby protocol commands, clients should generally not show them to the user as is, but either ignore them, or act according to the Inter-lobby-client data exchange protocol.

Command.Name: PING
Command.Description: The client should send this command every ~30 seconds, to maintain a constant connection to the server. The server will assume a timeout occured if it does not hear from the client for more than 60 seconds. To figure out how long a it takes a reply to from the server to the client, use a message ID with this command.

Command.Name: PONG
Command.Description: Used as a response to a command. You can determine how long the reply took by using a message ID with the command.

Command.Name: TASSERVER

Arguments.Argument: This is the lobby protocol version used by the server. The client may check if it supports this version before attempting to log in.

Beginning with Spring release 89 this will be the full version string, including the latest patchlevel, for example "89.0" or "101.2". The client should check if it has this Spring version before attempting to log in. If it does not find an exact match, but a compatible version (ie. "springVersion" is 101.2 but the client has 101.1) is available, the client can choose to use that instead.
Note that if the value of this parameter is "*", the client should simply ignore it since this means that the server does not contain any updates nor does it require latest Spring version (this is usually the case when the server is running in LAN mode).

This is server UDP port where the "NAT Help Server" is running. This is the port to which clients should send their UDP packets when trying to figure out their public UDP source port. This is used with some NAT traversal techniques (e.g. "hole punching").

Tells what mode the server is in. Currently valid are:
0 - normal mode
1 - LAN mode

Command.Description: This is the first message (i.e. "greeting message") that a client receives upon connecting to the server.

Command.Name: REGISTER

Arguments.Argument: Must be sent in encoded form (MD5 hash in base-64 form).
A valid email address. Case will not be considered.

Command.Description: The client sends this command when trying to register a new account. Note that the client mustn't already be logged in, or else the server will deny his request. If the server is running in LAN mode, this command will be ignored. The optional email allows account recovery via .
Command.Response: The server will respond with either a or command.

Command.Name: REGISTRATIONDENIED
Command.Description: Sent to a client that has just sent a command, if registration has been refused.

Command.Name: REGISTRATIONACCEPTED
Command.Description: Sent to a client who has just sent a command, if registration has been accepted.

Command.Name: RENAMEACCOUNT
Command.Description: Will rename the current account name to newUsername. The user has to be logged in for this to work. After the server renames the account, it will disconnect the client.
Command.Response: No formal response is required, although the server may reply with a command.

Command.Name: CHANGEPASSWORD
Command.Description: Will change the password of the users's account.
Command.Response: No formal response is required, although the server may reply with a command.

Command.Name: CHANGEEMAIL
Command.Description: Will change or, in case there was none previously associated, set the email associated with a user's account. The optional userName may only differ from the sender name iff the sender has admin or moderator status.
Command.Response: No formal response is required, although the server may reply with a command.

Command.Name: LOGIN

Arguments.Argument: Should be sent in encoded form (MD5 hash in base-64 form). Note that when the server is running in LAN mode, you can specify any username and password (the password will be ignored, but you must send some string anyway - you mustn't ommit it!)

An integer denoting the speed of the client's processor in MHz (or the value of the x+ tag if it is an AMD CPU). The client should leave this value at 0 if it can not figure out its CPU speed. HACK: Some lobby clients will report a special value instead of the processor frequency. This may be used by other lobby clients to display a specific icon or determine capabilities of a host. Known CPU identifiers are listed below:
6666 Springie (autohost) or Zero-K lobby client
6667 Springie with match-maker enabled
7777 WebLobby (web based lobby client), running at windows
7778 WebLobby (web based lobby client), running at linux
7779 WebLobby (web based lobby client), running mac
-1525630178 MUSLCE (Android lobby client)
This functionality will likely be deprecated once there is properties suppport.

The client should supply his local IP (e.g. 192.168.x.y, or whatever it uses) so the server can forward local IPs to clients behind the same NAT (this resolves some of the host/joining issues). If the client is unable to determine its local IP, he should send "*" instead.

This is a unique user identification number provided by the client-side software. It should be an unsigned integer encoded in hexadecimal form (see examples). Note that this parameter is optional - by default it is not used/set. the server will send an command to tell the client that he must provide a user ID, if needed. However, if the lobby client program was a using user ID before, it should send it along with this command.

When connecting, the lobby client can tell the lobby server that it is compatible with some optional functionalities that break backward compatibility. Each flag in this space separated parameter indicates a specific functionality (like IRC user/channel flags). By default, all the optional functionalities are considered as not supported by the client. For the current list of flags, see Recent changes - Version *-SNAPSHOT - Compatibility-Flags in the beginning of this document.

Command.Description:
Sent by a client when he is trying to log on to the server. The server may respond with a or command. Note, that if the client has not yet confirmed the server agreement, then server will send the agreement to the client upon receiving this command (the LOGIN command will be ignored; the client should resend LOGIN once the user has agreed to the agreement or disconnect from the server if the user has rejected the agreement).
Also see command.

Command.Name: ACCEPTED
Command.Description: Sent as a response to the command, if it succeeded. After the server has finished sending info about clients and battles, it will send a command indicating that it has finished sending the login info.

Command.Name: DENIED
Command.Description: Sent as a response to a failed command.

Command.Name: EXIT

Arguments.Argument: Clients may optionally specify a reason for quitting. The server is not required to use this reason in any way.

Command.Description: Clients should send this as their last command before severing the connection to indicate a clean and deliberate disconnect. The server is not requried to acknowledge this in any way.

Command.Name: LOGININFOEND
Command.Description:
Sent by the server, indicating that it has finished sending the login info (which is sent immediately after accepting the LOGIN command). This way, the client can figure out when the server has finished updating clients and battles info and can therefore figure out when the login sequence is finished.
Note that sending login info consists of 4 phases:
sending MOTD
sending list of all users currently logged on the server
sending info currently active battles
sending statuses of all users
This command is sent when the server has finished sending this info.

Command.Name: AGREEMENT

Arguments.Argument: The user agreement is sent in "Rich Text" format (.rtf file streamed via socket).

Command.Description: Sent by the server upon receiving a command, if the client has not yet agreed to the server's "terms-of-use". The server may send multiple AGREEMENT commands (which corresponds to multiple new lines in the agreement text), finishing it with an command. The client should send and then resend the command, or disconnect from the server if he has chosen to refuse the agreement.
Command.Response: No response is expected until is received. See that command for more info.

Command.Name: AGREEMENTEND
Command.Description: Sent by the server after multiple commands. This way, the server tells the client that he has finished sending the agreement (this is the time when the lobby client should popup the "agreement" screen and wait for the user to accept/reject it).
Command.Response: A command is expected from the client in case the user agreed to the agreement. Otherwise, the client should disconnect from the server.

Command.Name: CONFIRMAGREEMENT
Command.Description: Notifies the server that the user has confirmed the agreement. Also see the command.

Command.Name: MOTD
Command.Description: Sent by the server after the client has successfully logged in. The server may send multiple MOTD commands (each MOTD corresponds to one line, for example).

Command.Name: UDPSOURCEPORT
Command.Description: Sent as a response to a client's UDP packet (used with "hole punching" NAT traversal technique). For more info, see the Hole punching section in the beginnig of this document.

Command.Name: CLIENTIPPORT
Command.Description: Sent to the battle's host, notifying him about another client's IP address and his public UDP source port. The host needs to know public UDP source ports of all players in his battle in order for the Hole punching technique to work. The IP is needed for both NAT traversal methods ("hole punching" and "fixed source ports"). This command is sent to the the battle host immediately after a new user joins the battle (currently only if some NAT traversal technique is used).

Command.Name: HOSTPORT
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients participating in the battle (except for the host), notifying them about the new host port. This message will only be sent right before the host starts a game, if this battle is being hosted using "hole punching" NAT traversal technique. When a client receives this message, he should replace the battle's host port with this new port, so that when the game actually starts, he will connect to this new port, rather than to the port which the host selected when he initialy started the battle (with the command).

Command.Name: SERVERMSG
Command.Description: A general purpose message sent by the server. The lobby client program should display it either in the chat log or in some kind of system log, where the user will notice it. Also see the command.

Examples.Example: SERVERMSG Server is going down in 5 minutes for a restart, due to a new update.

Command.Name: SERVERMSGBOX

Arguments.Argument: If specified, the lobby client should ask the user if he wants this URL to be opened in a browser window. The lobby client should then (once the user clicked OK) launch the default browser and open this URL in there.

Command.Description: The client should open the message in a dialog window (and not just in the console). Also see the command.

Command.Name: ADDUSER

Arguments.Argument: A two-character country code based on ISO 3166 standard. See http://www.iso.org/iso/en/prods-services/iso3166ma/index.html
See the command for CPU field.
Unique ID bound to the account (can be used to track renammed accounts). This field is only provided if the lobby client sent the accountID compatibility flag ('a') in the command.

Command.Description: Tells the client that a new user joined a server. The client should add this user to his clients list, which he must maintain while he is connected to the server. The server will send multiple commands of this kind, once the client logs in, in order to provide the client with the list of all users currently connected.

Command.Name: REMOVEUSER
Command.Description: Indicates that a user disconnected from the server. The client should remove this user from his clients list, which he must maintain while he is connected to the server.

Command.Name: JOIN

Arguments.Argument: If the channel is locked, the client must supply the correct key to join the channel (clients with access >= Account.ADMIN_ACCESS can join locked channels withouth supplying the key - needed for the ChanServ bot).

Command.Description: Sent by a client trying to join a channel.

Command.Name: JOIN

Arguments.Argument: Name of the channel which the client has just joined (by previously sending the command).

Command.Description: Sent to a client who has successfully joined a channel.

Command.Name: JOINFAILED
Command.Description: Sent if joining a channel failed for some reason.

Command.Name: CHANNELS
Command.Description: Sent by a client when requesting the list of all channels on the server
Command.Response: A series of command, followed by an command.

Command.Name: CHANNEL

Arguments.Argument: Number of users in the channel.
Is omited if the topic is not set for the channel.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to a client who requested the channels list via the command. A series of these commands will be sent to the client, one for each open channel. A series of CHANNEL commands is followed by the command.

Command.Name: ENDOFCHANNELS
Command.Description: Sent to a client who previously requested the channel list, after a series of commands (one for each channel).

Command.Name: MUTELIST
Command.Description: Sent by a client when requesting the mute list of a channel.

Command.Name: MUTELISTBEGIN
Command.Description: Sent by the server when sending channel's mute list to the client.
Command.Response: 0 or more commands and finally by a command.

Command.Name: MUTELIST

Arguments.Argument: The form of this argument is not prescribed (it may vary from version to version). The lobby client program should simply display it as it receives it.

Command.Description: Multiple commands of this kind may be sent after a command (or none, if the mute list is empty).

Command.Name: MUTELISTEND
Command.Description: Sent by the server after it has finished sending the list of mutes for a channel. Also see the and commands.

Command.Name: CHANNELTOPIC

Arguments.Argument: Time in milliseconds since Jan 1, 1970 (UTC). Divide by 1000 to get unix time.

Command.Description: Sent to a client who just joined the channel, if some topic is set for this channel.

Command.Name: CHANNELTOPIC
Command.Description: Sent a by privileged user who is trying to change a channel's topic. Use "*" as topic if you wish to remove the topic.

Command.Name: CLIENTS
Command.Description: Sent to a client who just joined the channel. Note: Multiple commands of this kind can be sent in a row. The server takes the list of clients in a channel, separates it into several lines and sends each line seperately. This ensures no line is too long, because the client may have some limit set on the maximum line-length and it could ignore the line if it was too long. Also note, that the clients user-name is sent in this list too! So when the client receives a JOIN command, he should not add his name in the client list of the channel, but he should wait for the CLIENTS command, which will contain his name too and he will add himself automatically then.

Command.Name: JOINED
Command.Description: Sent to all clients in a channel (except the new client) when a new user joins the channel.

Command.Name: LEAVE
Command.Description: Sent by a client when he is trying to leave a channel. When the client is disconnected, he is automatically removed from all channels.

Command.Name: LEFT
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a channel when some client left this channel. WARNING: The server does not send this command to a client that has just left a channel, because there is no need to, as the client who has left the channel knows that already. A client that was kicked from the channel is notified about it via the command.

Command.Name: FORCELEAVECHANNEL
Command.Description: Sent by a client (moderator), requsting that a user be removed from the channel. The user will be notified with a command.

Command.Name: FORCELEAVECHANNEL
Command.Description: Sent to a user who has just been kicked from the channel #chanName by user "userName". The lobby client should now internally close/detach from the channel, as he was removed from the clients list of #channame on the server side.

Command.Name: CHANNELMESSAGE
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a channel. Used to broadcast messages in a channel.

Command.Name: SAY
Command.Description: Send a chat message to a specific channel. The client has to join the channel first, to be allowed to use this command.

Command.Name: SAID
Command.Description: Sent to all clients participating in a specific channel when one of the clients sent a chat message to it (including the author of the message).

Command.Name: SAYEX
Command.Description: Sent by any client when he is trying to say something in "/me" IRC style. Also see the command.

Command.Name: SAIDEX
Command.Description: Sent by the server when a client said something using the command.

Command.Name: SAYPRIVATE
Command.Description: Send a private chat message to an other client.

Command.Name: SAIDPRIVATE
Command.Description: Indicates that a user sent a private chat message to the receiving client.

Command.Name: OPENBATTLE

Arguments.Argument: Can be 0 or 1 (0 = normal battle, 1 = battle replay)
NAT traversal method used by the host. Must be one of: 0: none 1: Hole punching 2: Fixed source ports
Must be "*" if founder does not wish to have password-protected game.
A signed 32-bit integer (acquired via the unitsync library).
A signed 32-bit integer (acquired via the unitsync library).
For example: 'my spring spring'
For example: '94.1.1-1062-g9d16c2d develop'

Command.Description: Sent by the client when he is trying to open a new battle. ( Compatibility-Flag need: 'eb' ) The client becomes a founder of this battle, if the command is successful.
Command.Response: The cient is notified about this command's success via the / commands.

Command.Name: OPENBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent to a client who previously sent a command, if the client's request to open a new battle has been approved. If the server rejected the request, the client is notified via the command. The server first sends a , then this command (this is important - the client must have the battle in his battle list before he receives this command!).

Command.Name: BATTLEOPENED

Arguments.Argument: Can be 0 or 1 (0 = normal battle, 1 = battle replay)
NAT traversal method used by the host. Must be one of: 0: none 1: Hole punching 2: Fixed source ports
Username of the client who started this battle.
A boolean - must be "0" (meaning false) or "1"!
A signed 32-bit integer as returned from (acquired via the unitsync library).
For example: 'my hacked spring'
For example: '94.1.1-1062-g9d16c2d develop'

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all registered users, when a new battle has been opened. ( Compatibility-Flag need: 'eb' ) A series of instances of this command are sent to user when he logs in (1 command for each battle).

Command.Name: BATTLECLOSED
Command.Description: Sent when the founder has closed a battle (or if he was disconnected).

Command.Name: JOINBATTLE

Arguments.Argument: A random, client-generated string, wich will be written to script.txt by the host, to avoid account spoofing (= someone is trying to join the battle under a wrong user-name). If set, the password has to be set too, even if it is empty.

Command.Description: Sent by a client trying to join a battle. The password is an optional parameter.

Command.Name: JOINBATTLE

Arguments.Argument: A signed 32-bit integer.

Command.Description: Tells the client that he has just joined the battle successfully. The server will also send a series of commands after this command, so that the user will get the battle statuses of all the clients in the battle.

Command.Name: JOINBATTLEREQUEST
Command.Description: Sent by the server to a battle founder, each time a client requests to join his battle, if the battle founder supports the battle authorization system (i.e., he provided the battle authorization compatibility flag ('b') in the command).
Command.Response: When the client receives this command, he must send either a or a command to the server.

Command.Name: JOINBATTLEACCEPT
Command.Description: Sent by a client in response to a command in order to allow the user to join the battle.

Command.Name: JOINBATTLEDENY
Command.Description: Sent by a client in response to a command in order to prevent the user from joining the battle.

Command.Name: JOINEDBATTLE

Arguments.Argument: A random, client-generated string, wich will be written to script.txt by the host, to avoid account spoofing (= someone is trying to join the battle under a wrong user-name).

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients when a new client joins the battle.

Command.Name: LEFTBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all users when a client left a battle (or got disconnected from the server).

Command.Name: LEAVEBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent by the client when he leaves a battle. Also sent by a founder of the battle when he closes his battle.

Command.Name: JOINBATTLEFAILED
Command.Description: Tells a user that just tried to join a battle that he has been rejected.

Command.Name: OPENBATTLEFAILED
Command.Description: Tells a user that just tried to open a battle that this request has been rejected.

Command.Name: UPDATEBATTLEINFO

Arguments.Argument: Assume that spectator count is 0, if battle type is 0 (normal battle) and 1 if battle type is 1 (battle replay), as the founder of the battle is automatically set as a spectator in that case.
A boolean ("0" (for false) or "1"). Note that when the client creates a battle, the server assumes it is unlocked (by default). The client must make sure it uses this same default.
A signed 32-bit integer. See the command for more info.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all registered clients, telling them some of the parameters of the battle changed. A battle's internal changes, like starting metal, energy, starting position etc., are sent only to clients participating in the battle (via the command).

Command.Name: UPDATEBATTLEINFO

Arguments.Argument: A boolean ("0" (for false) or "1"). Note that when the client creates a battle, the server assumes it is unlocked (by default). The client must make sure it uses this same default.
A signed 32-bit integer. See the command for more info.
Must NOT contain the file extension!

Command.Description: Sent by the founder of the battle, telling the server that some of the "external" parameters of the battle changed.

Command.Name: SAYBATTLE
Command.Description: Send a chat message to all clients participating in a battle. A 'battleID' argument is not required, since every user can participate in only one battle at a time. If the user is not participating in any battle, receiption of this command is considered invalid and will therefore be ignored.

Command.Name: SAIDBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent to the participants of a battle when a client sent a chat message to it, using the command. A 'battleID' is not required, since every client knows which battle he is participating in, since every client may participate in only one battle at a time. If the client is not participating in any battle, he should ignore this command or raise an error.

Command.Name: SAYBATTLEEX
Command.Description: Sent by any client participating in a battle when he wants to say something in "/me" IRC style. The server can forge this command too (for example, when the founder of the battle kicks a user, the server uses this command to indicate what just happened).

Command.Name: SAIDBATTLEEX
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients participating in a battle when the client sent the command.

Command.Name: MYSTATUS

Arguments.Argument:
A signed integer in text form (e.g. "1234"). Each bit has its meaning:
b0 = in game (0 - normal, 1 - in game)
b1 = away status (0 - normal, 1 - away)
b2-b4 = rank (see Account class implementation for description of rank) - client is not allowed to change rank bits himself (only server may set them).
b5 = access status (tells us whether this client is a server moderator or not) - client is not allowed to change this bit himself (only server may set them).
b6 = bot mode (0 - normal user, 1 - automated bot). This bit is copied from user's account and can not be changed by the client himself. Bots differ from human players in that they are fully automated and that some anti-flood limitations do not apply to them.

Command.Description: Sent by a client to inform the server about his changed status. To figure out if a battle is "in-game", a client must check the in-game status of the host.

Command.Name: CLIENTSTATUS

Arguments.Argument: See the command for possible values of this parameter.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all registered clients, indicating that a client's status changed. Note that client's status is considered 0 if not indicated otherwise (for example, when you login, the server sends only statuses of those clients whose statuses differ from 0, to save bandwidth).

Command.Name: MYBATTLESTATUS

Arguments.Argument:
An integer, but with limited range: 0..2147483647 (use signed int and consider only positive values and zero) This number is sent as text. Each bit has its meaning:
b0 = undefined (reserved for future use)
b1 = ready (0=not ready, 1=ready)
b2..b5 = team no. (from 0 to 15. b2 is LSB, b5 is MSB)
b6..b9 = ally team no. (from 0 to 15. b6 is LSB, b9 is MSB)
b10 = mode (0 = spectator, 1 = normal player)
b11..b17 = handicap (7-bit number. Must be in range 0..100). Note: Only host can change handicap values of the players in the battle (with HANDICAP command). These 7 bits are always ignored in this command. They can only be changed using HANDICAP command.
b18..b21 = reserved for future use (with pre 0.71 versions these bits were used for team color index)
b22..b23 = sync status (0 = unknown, 1 = synced, 2 = unsynced)
b24..b27 = side (e.g.: arm, core, tll, ... Side index can be between 0 and 15, inclusive)
b28..b31 = undefined (reserved for future use)

Should be a 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red). Example: 255 stands for $000000FF.

Command.Description: Sent by a client to the server, telling him his battle status changed.

Command.Name: CLIENTBATTLESTATUS

Arguments.Argument: See the command for possible values of this argument.
Uses the same format as the one used with the command.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to users participating in a battle when one of the clients changes his battle status.

Command.Name: REQUESTBATTLESTATUS
Command.Description: Sent by the server to a user which just opened a battle or joined one. This command is sent after all commands for all clients have been sent. This way, the user can choose a suitable team, ally-team and color, since he knows the battle statuses of other clients already.
Command.Response: When a client receives this command, he has to send the command to the server, so that the server can synchronize the battle status with the other clients.

Command.Name: HANDICAP

Arguments.Argument: Must be in range [0, 100] (inclusive).

Command.Description: Sent by the founder of the battle when changing a user's handicap value (which is part of his battle status). Only the founder can change other users handicap values (even they themselves ca not change it).

Command.Name: KICKFROMBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent by the founder of the battle when he kicks a client out of the battle. The server removes the client from the battle and notifies him about it via the command.

Command.Name: FORCEQUITBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent to a client that just got kicked by the battle founder, using the command. the client does not need to send the command, as that is already done by the server. The only purpose of this command, is to notify the client that he was kicked from the battle. Note that the client should close the battle internally, since he is no longer a part of it (or he can do that once he receives the command containing his user name).

Command.Name: FORCETEAMNO
Command.Description: Sent by the founder of a battle when he is trying to force some other client's team number to 'teamNo'. The server will update the client's battle status automatically.

Command.Name: FORCEALLYNO
Command.Description: Sent by the founder of a battle when he is trying to force some other client's ally number to 'allyno'. The server will update the client's battle status automatically.

Command.Name: FORCETEAMCOLOR

Arguments.Argument: Should be a 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red). Example: 255 stands for $000000FF.

Command.Description: Sent by the founder of a battle when he is trying to force some other client's team color to 'color'. The server will update the client's battle status automatically.

Command.Name: FORCESPECTATORMODE
Command.Description: Sent by the founder of a battle when he is trying to force some other client's mode to 'spectator'. The server will update the client's battle status automatically.

Command.Name: DISABLEUNITS

Arguments.Argument: Multiple units may follow, but at least one must be present in the arguments list.

Command.Description: Sent by the founder of a battle, telling the server that he disabled one or more units. At least one unit name must be passed as an argument.

Command.Name: DISABLEUNITS

Arguments.Argument: Multiple units may follow, but at least one must be present in the arguments list.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a battle except for the founder, telling them that some units have been added to disabled units list. Also see the command.

Command.Name: ENABLEUNITS

Arguments.Argument: Multiple units may follow, but at least one must be present in the arguments list.

Command.Description: Sent by the founder of the battle, telling the server that he enabled one or more previously disabled units. At least one unit name must be passed as an argument.

Command.Name: ENABLEUNITS

Arguments.Argument: Multiple units may follow, but at least one must be present in the arguments list.

Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a battle except for the founder, telling them that some units have been removed from disabled units list.

Command.Name: ENABLEALLUNITS
Command.Description: Sent by the founder of a battle, telling the server that he enabled ALL units and, and is thus clearing the disabled units list.

Command.Name: ENABLEALLUNITS
Command.Description: Sent by the server to all clients in a battle except for the founder, telling them that the disabled units list has been cleared.

Command.Name: RING
Command.Description: Sent by a client to the server when trying to play a "ring" sound to an other user. Only privileged users can ring everyone, although "normal" clients can ring players participating in their battle when they are hosting.

Command.Name: RING
Command.Description: Telling a client that a user just rang. As a consequence, the client should play the "ring" sound.

Command.Name: REDIRECT
Command.Description: Sent by the server when running in "redirection mode". When a client connects, the server will send him only this message and disconnect the socket immediately. The client should connect to the given IP, in that case. This command may be useful when the official server address changes, so that clients are automatically redirected to the new one.

Command.Name: BROADCAST
Command.Description: Sent by the server when an urgent message has to be delivered to all users. The lobby client program should display this message either in some system log or in some message box (the user has to see this message!).

Command.Name: ADDBOT

Arguments.Argument: Should be a 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red).

Command.Description: Allows a client to add a bot to the battle.

Command.Name: ADDBOT

Arguments.Argument: helps the client verify that the bot is meant for his battle.
Should be 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red).

Command.Description: Indicates that a client has added a bot to the battle.

Command.Name: REMOVEBOT
Command.Description: Removes a bot from the battle.

Command.Name: REMOVEBOT

Arguments.Argument: helps the client verify that the bot is meant for his battle.

Command.Description: Indicates that a bot has been removed from the battle.

Command.Name: UPDATEBOT

Arguments.Argument: Similar to that of the normal client's, see for more info.
Should be a 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red).

Command.Description: Sent by a client when he is trying to update the status of a bot. Only the bot owner and battle host may update a bot's status.

Command.Name: UPDATEBOT

Arguments.Argument: helps the client verify that the bot is meant for his battle.
Similar to that of the normal client's, see for more info.
Should be a 32-bit signed integer in decimal form (e.g. 255 and not FF) where each color channel should occupy 1 byte (e.g. in hexdecimal: $00BBGGRR, B = blue, G = green, R = red).

Command.Description: Sent by the server notifying a client in the battle that one of the bots just got his status updated. Also see the command.

Command.Name: ADDSTARTRECT
Command.Description: Adds a start rectangle for the 'allyno' ally team. Only the battle foudner may use this command. See lobby client implementations and Spring docs for more info on this one. "left", "top", "right" and "bottom" refer to a virtual rectangle that is 200x200 in size, where coordinates should be in the interval [0, 200].

Command.Name: ADDSTARTRECT
Command.Description: Sent by the server to clients participating in a battle (except for the host). See lobby client implementations and Spring docs for more info on this one. "left", "top", "right" and "bottom" refer to a virtual rectangle that is 200x200 in size, where coordinates should be in the interval [0, 200].

Command.Name: REMOVESTARTRECT
Command.Description: Removing a start rectangle the for 'allyNo' ally team. Sent by the host of the battle. See client implementations and Spring docs for more info on this one.

Command.Name: REMOVESTARTRECT
Command.Description: Removing a start rectangle the for 'allyNo' ally team. Sent to clients participating in a battle (except for the host). Also see command.

Command.Name: SCRIPTSTART
Command.Description:
Sent by a client who is hosting a battle replay game, indicating he is now sending the game script used in the original replay to the server. The server will then forward this script to all other participants in his battle. The correct sequence of commands when sending the script file is this:
1) SCRIPTSTART command
2) multiple SCRIPT commands
3) SCRIPTEND command

Command.Name: SCRIPTSTART
Command.Description: Sent by the server to clients participating in a battle replay, indicating that ther server will now begin sending the game script from the original replay file. Also see the (client) command comments.

Command.Name: SCRIPT

Arguments.Argument: This is a line read from the replay script file. Use one SCRIPT command for each line!.

Command.Description: Sent by a client who previously sent a command. Multiple commands of this type are expected after , ending with as the last command in the sequence. Also see the (client) command comments.

Command.Name: SCRIPT

Arguments.Argument: This is a line read from the replay script file. Use one SCRIPT command for each line!.

Command.Description: Sent by the server after sending a command. Multiple commands of this type are expected after a command, ending with as the last command in the sequence. Also see the (client) command comments.

Command.Name: SCRIPTEND
Command.Description: Indicates the end of the game script from the battle replay. Also see the (client) command comments.

Command.Name: SCRIPTEND
Command.Description: Indicates the end of the game script from the battle replay. Also see the (client) command comments.

Command.Name: SETSCRIPTTAGS
Command.Description:
Sent by a client (battle host), to inform other clients about current battle configuration (start positions type, mod options, map options...). Only the battle host itself needs to write the corresponding script tags into script.txt, other battle clients should merely use them for display purposes.
The [pair] format is "key=value can have spaces". Keys may not contain spaces, and are expected to use the '/' character to separate tables (see example). In version 0.35 of TASServer, the command UPDATEBATTLEDETAILS was completely replaced by this command. The list of attributes that were replaced (with example usage):
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/StartMetal=1000
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/StartEnergy=1000
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/MaxUnits=500
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/StartPosType=1
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/GameMode=0
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/LimitDGun=1
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/DiminishingMMs=0
SETSCRIPTTAGS GAME/GhostedBuildings=1
Though in reality, all tags are joined together in a single command. Note that when specifying multiple key+value pairs, they must be separated by TAB characters. See the examples bellow.

Command.Name: SETSCRIPTTAGS
Command.Description: Relayed from battle host's message. A client lobby program must process these tags and apply them accordingly to the GUI presenting current battle configuration to the player.

Command.Name: REMOVESCRIPTTAGS
Command.Description: Sent by a client (battle host), to inform other clients that a battle configuration setting has been removed (this is mainly usefull when changing map with map options).

Command.Name: REMOVESCRIPTTAGS
Command.Description: Relayed from battle host's message. A client lobby program has to remove these from the GUI presenting current battle configuration to the player.

Command.Name: TESTLOGIN
Command.Description: Used to test if user-name and password are valid. Currently, this command is restricted to users with admin access only. It is meant to be used with some external server process to identify a user via a web login form and create a session cookie based on that.

Command.Name: TESTLOGINACCEPT
Command.Description: Used as a response to a command in case the user-name/password pair is valid. Use message ID to bind the response to a request.

Command.Name: TESTLOGINDENY
Command.Description: Used as a response to a command in case the user-name/password pair is not valid. Use message ID to bind the response to a request.

Command.Name: ACQUIREUSERID
Command.Description: When a client receives this command, he should immediately respond with a command. If the client does not have a user ID associated yet, he should generate some random ID (unsigned 32 bit integer), and save it permanently as his user ID. He will then provide this user ID each time he logs on to the server via the command.

Command.Name: USERID

Arguments.Argument: Must be an unsigned a 32 bit integer, in a hexadecimal form.

Command.Description: Sent as response to a command.

Command.Name: GETINGAMETIME
Command.Description: The server replies with a indicating the user's ingame time in minutes.

Command.Name: FORCEJOINBATTLE
Command.Description: A client may send this command if he is a battle host or a lobby moderator. The server will decide if they are, and send a command to the addressed user. See the Match-Making section in the beginning of this document for more details.

Command.Name: FORCEJOINBATTLE
Command.Description: Sent to a user specified in a previous command which was received on the server form an other client (host or lobby moderator). The receiving client must subsequently comply by sending a command to the server. See the Match-Making section in the beginning of this document for more details.

Command.Name: FORCEJOINBATTLEFAILED
Command.Description: Sent by the server to the user who just sent a request, in the case of it being rejected by the server.

Command.Name: LISTCOMPFLAGS
Command.Description: A client may send this command after it has received to query the server for supported comp-flags that may be specified on .

Command.Name: COMPFLAGS
Command.Description: Sent as a response to a command. The server sends a list of supported comp-flags that may be specified by the client on .

Command.Name: CONNECTUSER

Arguments.Argument: This might be IP v4 or v6, and has to be in the form "IP:Port".

Command.Description: The client may send this command if it is a battle host or lobby moderator. The server will decide if they are, and send to the affected user, or to the client issuing this command. See the Decoupling games from battle-rooms section in the beginning of this document for more details.

Command.Name: CONNECTUSER

Arguments.Argument: This might be IP v4 or v6, and has to be in the form "IP:Port".

Command.Description: Instructs the client to connect spring to the given IP:port with the script password given in . See the Decoupling games from battle-rooms section in the beginning of this document for more details.

Command.Name: CONNECTUSERFAILED
Command.Description: Sent by the server to the user who just sent a request, in the case of it being rejected by the server.

Command.Name: SAYDATA
Command.Description: Send a data message to a specific channel. The client has to join the channel first, to be allowed to use this command. For more info, see the Inter-lobby-client data exchange section in the beginning of this document.

Command.Name: SAIDDATA
Command.Description: Sent to all clients participating in a specific channel when one of the clients sent a data message to it (including the author of the message). For more info, see the Inter-lobby-client data exchange section in the beginning of this document.

Command.Name: SAYDATAPRIVATE
Command.Description: Send a private data message to an other client. For more info, see the Inter-lobby-client data exchange section in the beginning of this document.

Command.Name: SAIDDATAPRIVATE
Command.Description: Indicates that a user sent a private data message to the receiving client. For more info, see the Inter-lobby-client data exchange section in the beginning of this document.

Command.Name: SAYDATABATTLE
Command.Description: Send a data message to all clients participating in a battle. A 'battleID' argument is not required, since every user can participate in only one battle at a time. If the user is not participating in any battle, receiption of this command is considered invalid and will therefore be ignored. For more info, see the Inter-lobby-client data exchange section in the beginning of this document.

Command.Name: SAIDDATABATTLE
Command.Description: Sent to the participants of a battle when a client sent a data message to it, using the command. A 'battleID' is not required, since every client knows which battle he is participating in, since every client may participate in only one battle at a time. If the client is not participating in any battle, he should ignore this command or raise an error. For more info, see the Inter-lobby-client data exchange section in the beginning of this document.

Command.Name: RECOVERACCOUNT

Arguments.Argument: The email address associated with a given username. Case will not be considered.

Command.Description: Sends an e-mail with account recovery information. If one or more accounts with the given email address (and optional userName) exists, the server sends an email to that address containing the associated username(s) and a means to reset the password(s). This could either be a new temporary password or for example a one-time-token that authorizes setting up a new password via some webinterface. If no account is found matching the given search criterias, no error is returned.
